Chapter 1: Measurement

Foundation of Scientific Physics

Master the fundamental concepts of measurement, units, and dimensional analysis that form the bedrock of all physics - from basic concepts to advanced applications.

Introduction 0%

🌟 Why Learn About Measurement?

🔰 Think About This:

Imagine trying to cook without measuring ingredients, or building a house without measuring lumber. Physics is similar - we need precise measurements to understand how the universe works! Every law of physics started with careful observations and measurements.

Physics is fundamentally an experimental science. Every law, theory, and principle we know about the universe comes from careful observation and measurement. When Galileo dropped objects from the Tower of Pisa, when Newton observed falling apples, when Einstein predicted the bending of light - all these breakthroughs required precise measurement.

Consider this amazing fact: the GPS in your phone works because engineers understand Einstein's theory of relativity with incredible precision. Without accurate measurement of time (to nanoseconds) and the effects of gravity on time, your GPS would be off by miles!

🔬 The Power of Precise Measurement

The 2017 detection of gravitational waves by LIGO required measuring distance changes smaller than 1/10,000th the width of a proton - that's like measuring the distance to the nearest star to within the width of a human hair!

What You'll Master in This Chapter

  • 🎯 Physical Quantities: Understand scalars, vectors, and operational definitions
  • 📏 SI Units: Master the international standard for all scientific measurements
  • 🧮 Dimensional Analysis: Use this powerful tool to check equations and derive relationships
  • 🎯 Precision & Errors: Quantify uncertainty and combine errors in calculations

🎓 For Advanced Students:

Modern physics pushes measurement to quantum limits. The Heisenberg uncertainty principle fundamentally limits how precisely we can simultaneously measure certain pairs of properties. This isn't just a technical limitation - it's a fundamental feature of reality itself.

1.1 Physical Quantities, Standards, and Units

What Are Physical Quantities?

A physical quantity is any measurable property of matter or energy. Understanding these is crucial for all of physics!

📊 Two Categories of Physical Quantities:

  • Scalar Quantities: Have magnitude only
    Examples: mass (5 kg), time (10 s), temperature (25°C), energy (100 J)
  • Vector Quantities: Have both magnitude and direction
    Examples: displacement (5 m north), velocity (10 m/s east), acceleration (9.8 m/s² downward)

Operational Definitions

Each physical quantity must have an operational definition - a precise description of how to measure it. This ensures anyone can reproduce the measurement anywhere in the world.

📝 Example: Defining Velocity

Operational definition: "Change in position divided by time interval"

v = Δx/Δt

This tells us exactly how to measure velocity: measure the change in position, measure the time it took, then divide.

Characteristics of Good Physical Standards

For measurements to be meaningful worldwide, our standards must be:

  1. Accessible: Can be reproduced in laboratories worldwide
  2. Invariable: Unchanging over time and location
  3. Precise: Allows measurement to desired accuracy
  4. Reproducible: Independent measurements yield consistent results

🤔 Quick Check Questions:

Q1. Is speed a scalar or vector quantity? What about velocity? +

Answer: Speed is a scalar (magnitude only: "50 km/h"), while velocity is a vector (magnitude + direction: "50 km/h north"). This distinction is crucial in physics!

Q2. Why can't we use a rubber band as a standard for length? +

Answer: A rubber band stretches with temperature and tension, violating the "invariable" requirement. A good standard must be unchanging over time and conditions.

1.2 The International System of Units (SI)

The International System of Units (SI) provides a standardized framework for measurement that enables scientists worldwide to communicate effectively. This system is built on seven fundamental base units from which all other units are derived.

Base Units of SI

Physical Quantity SI Base Unit Symbol Definition
Length meter m Distance light travels in vacuum in 1/299,792,458 second
Mass kilogram kg Mass of the international prototype kilogram
Time second s Duration of 9,192,631,770 periods of cesium-133 radiation
Electric Current ampere A Current producing force of 2×10⁻⁷ N/m between parallel wires
Temperature kelvin K 1/273.16 of thermodynamic temperature of water's triple point
Amount of Substance mole mol Amount containing as many particles as atoms in 0.012 kg carbon-12
Luminous Intensity candela cd Luminous intensity of 1/683 watt per steradian at 540×10¹² Hz

Derived Units

Many physical quantities are expressed using derived units, which are combinations of base units. Some common derived units have special names:

Quantity Unit Name Symbol Base Unit Expression
Force newton N kg⋅m⋅s⁻²
Energy joule J kg⋅m²⋅s⁻²
Power watt W kg⋅m²⋅s⁻³
Pressure pascal Pa kg⋅m⁻¹⋅s⁻²
Electric Charge coulomb C A⋅s
Voltage volt V kg⋅m²⋅s⁻³⋅A⁻¹

SI Prefixes

SI prefixes allow us to express very large or very small quantities efficiently:

Prefix Symbol Power of 10 Decimal Value Example
tera T 10¹² 1,000,000,000,000 1 TW = 10¹² W
giga G 10⁹ 1,000,000,000 1 GHz = 10⁹ Hz
mega M 10⁶ 1,000,000 1 MHz = 10⁶ Hz
kilo k 10³ 1,000 1 km = 10³ m
centi c 10⁻² 0.01 1 cm = 10⁻² m
milli m 10⁻³ 0.001 1 mm = 10⁻³ m
micro μ 10⁻⁶ 0.000001 1 μm = 10⁻⁶ m
nano n 10⁻⁹ 0.000000001 1 nm = 10⁻⁹ m
pico p 10⁻¹² 0.000000000001 1 pm = 10⁻¹² m

Practice Problems

1
Express 0.000035 meters using appropriate SI prefix notation.
+

Solution:

0.000035 m = 3.5 × 10⁻⁵ m

Since 10⁻⁵ = 10⁻⁶ × 10¹ = μ × 10, we can write:

3.5 × 10⁻⁵ m = 35 × 10⁻⁶ m = 35 μm

Alternatively: 3.5 × 10⁻⁵ m = 0.035 × 10⁻³ m = 0.035 mm

2
Convert 2.5 GW to watts and express in scientific notation.
+

Solution:

G (giga) = 10⁹

2.5 GW = 2.5 × 10⁹ W = 2.5 × 10⁹ watts

This represents 2,500,000,000 watts.

3
A force of 250 N is applied. Express this force in terms of base SI units.
+

Solution:

Newton (N) is a derived unit for force.

From Newton's second law: F = ma

1 N = 1 kg⋅m⋅s⁻²

Therefore: 250 N = 250 kg⋅m⋅s⁻²

4
Which of the following is NOT a base SI unit? (a) kilogram (b) ampere (c) newton (d) kelvin
+

Answer: (c) newton

Explanation:

• kilogram (kg) - base unit for mass

• ampere (A) - base unit for electric current

• kelvin (K) - base unit for temperature

• newton (N) - derived unit for force (kg⋅m⋅s⁻²)

The newton is derived from base units and is therefore not a base unit itself.

1.3 Dimensional Analysis

Dimensional analysis is a powerful tool for checking equations, converting units, and solving physics problems. It uses the principle that physical equations must be dimensionally consistent - both sides must have the same dimensions.

Fundamental Dimensions

All physical quantities can be expressed in terms of fundamental dimensions:

Physical Quantity Dimension Symbol SI Base Unit
Length [L] meter (m)
Mass [M] kilogram (kg)
Time [T] second (s)
Electric Current [I] ampere (A)
Temperature [Θ] kelvin (K)
Amount of Substance [N] mole (mol)
Luminous Intensity [J] candela (cd)

Derived Dimensions

Common derived quantities and their dimensional expressions:

Physical Quantity Dimensional Formula SI Unit
Area [L²] m²
Volume [L³] m³
Velocity [LT⁻¹] m/s
Acceleration [LT⁻²] m/s²
Force [MLT⁻²] N (kg⋅m/s²)
Energy [ML²T⁻²] J (kg⋅m²/s²)
Power [ML²T⁻³] W (kg⋅m²/s³)
Pressure [ML⁻¹T⁻²] Pa (kg/(m⋅s²))

Unit Conversion Using Dimensional Analysis

The conversion factor method uses the principle that multiplying by a ratio equal to 1 doesn't change the value:

Example: Convert 75 mph to m/s

75 mph × (1609 m/1 mile) × (1 hr/3600 s) = 33.5 m/s

Checking Equation Validity

Dimensional analysis can verify if an equation is physically meaningful by ensuring both sides have identical dimensions.

Practice Problems

1
Find the dimensional formula for kinetic energy (KE = ½mv²).
+

Solution:

KE = ½mv²

Dimensions of mass: [M]

Dimensions of velocity: [LT⁻¹]

Dimensions of v²: [LT⁻¹]² = [L²T⁻²]

Therefore: [KE] = [M][L²T⁻²] = [ML²T⁻²]

This matches the dimensional formula for energy.

2
Convert 60 km/h to m/s using dimensional analysis.
+

Solution:

60 km/h × (1000 m/1 km) × (1 h/3600 s)

= 60 × 1000/3600 m/s

= 60,000/3600 m/s

= 16.7 m/s

3
Check if the equation v = at + v₀ is dimensionally consistent.
+

Solution:

Left side: [v] = [LT⁻¹]

Right side: [at] + [v₀]

• [a] = [LT⁻²]

• [t] = [T]

• [at] = [LT⁻²][T] = [LT⁻¹]

• [v₀] = [LT⁻¹]

Both terms on right side: [LT⁻¹] + [LT⁻¹] = [LT⁻¹]

Yes, the equation is dimensionally consistent.

4
A student claims that distance d = vt + ½at³. Is this equation correct?
+

Solution:

Check dimensional consistency:

Left side: [d] = [L]

Right side: [vt] + [½at³]

• [vt] = [LT⁻¹][T] = [L] ✓

• [at³] = [LT⁻²][T³] = [LT] ✗

The second term has dimensions of [LT], not [L].

No, this equation is dimensionally incorrect.

The correct equation is d = vt + ½at².

1.4 Precision, Accuracy, and Error Analysis

Understanding measurement uncertainty is crucial in physics. We distinguish between precision (repeatability) and accuracy (correctness), and learn to quantify and minimize errors in experimental measurements.

Precision vs. Accuracy

Concept Definition Analogy
Precision How close repeated measurements are to each other Tight grouping of arrows on target
Accuracy How close a measurement is to the true value Arrows hitting the bullseye

Types of Errors

1. Systematic Errors

  • Definition: Consistent, repeatable errors that shift all measurements in the same direction
  • Causes: Faulty instruments, environmental factors, procedural mistakes
  • Effect: Reduces accuracy but not precision
  • Examples: Uncalibrated scale, parallax error, thermal expansion

2. Random Errors

  • Definition: Unpredictable variations that fluctuate randomly around the true value
  • Causes: Human limitations, electrical noise, environmental fluctuations
  • Effect: Reduces precision
  • Examples: Reading variations, timing uncertainties, atmospheric turbulence

Significant Figures

Significant figures indicate the precision of a measurement:

Rules for Counting Significant Figures:

  1. All non-zero digits are significant: 1.234 has 4 significant figures
  2. Zeros between non-zero digits are significant: 1.035 has 4 significant figures
  3. Leading zeros are not significant: 0.0123 has 3 significant figures
  4. Trailing zeros after decimal point are significant: 1.230 has 4 significant figures
  5. Trailing zeros without decimal point may or may not be significant: 1200 (ambiguous)

Operations with Significant Figures:

  • Addition/Subtraction: Round to the least precise decimal place
  • Multiplication/Division: Round to the fewest significant figures

Error Propagation

When combining measurements, uncertainties propagate according to specific rules:

Operation Formula Error Propagation
Addition z = x + y δz = √(δx² + δy²)
Subtraction z = x - y δz = √(δx² + δy²)
Multiplication z = xy δz/z = √((δx/x)² + (δy/y)²)
Division z = x/y δz/z = √((δx/x)² + (δy/y)²)

Practice Problems

1
Calculate: 12.34 + 5.6 + 0.789. Express with proper significant figures.
+

Solution:

12.34 (2 decimal places)

+ 5.6 (1 decimal place) ← least precise

+ 0.789 (3 decimal places)

= 18.729

Round to 1 decimal place: 18.7

2
Calculate: 2.5 × 3.14159. Express with proper significant figures.
+

Solution:

2.5 has 2 significant figures ← fewest

3.14159 has 6 significant figures

2.5 × 3.14159 = 7.853975

Round to 2 significant figures: 7.9

3
A measurement gives x = 15.2 ± 0.3 cm and y = 8.7 ± 0.2 cm. Find z = x + y with uncertainty.
+

Solution:

z = x + y = 15.2 + 8.7 = 23.9 cm

For addition: δz = √(δx² + δy²)

δz = √(0.3² + 0.2²) = √(0.09 + 0.04) = √0.13 = 0.36 cm

Therefore: z = 23.9 ± 0.4 cm

4
How many significant figures are in: (a) 0.00234 (b) 1.200 (c) 3400?
+

Solutions:

(a) 0.00234: Leading zeros don't count → 3 significant figures

(b) 1.200: Trailing zeros after decimal count → 4 significant figures

(c) 3400: Ambiguous without decimal point → 2-4 significant figures

To clarify (c), write as 3.4 × 10³ (2 sig figs) or 3.400 × 10³ (4 sig figs)

Chapter 1 Assessment

Test your understanding of measurement principles with this comprehensive assessment. These problems integrate concepts from all sections of this chapter.

Comprehensive Problems

1
A student measures the length of a table five times and gets: 1.52 m, 1.49 m, 1.53 m, 1.51 m, 1.50 m. The true length is 1.65 m. Comment on the precision and accuracy of these measurements.
+

Solution:

Analysis of Precision:

Range = 1.53 - 1.49 = 0.04 m

The measurements are clustered closely together (small range), indicating high precision.

Analysis of Accuracy:

Average = (1.52 + 1.49 + 1.53 + 1.51 + 1.50)/5 = 1.51 m

Error = |1.51 - 1.65| = 0.14 m = 14 cm

This is a significant deviation from the true value, indicating low accuracy.

Conclusion: The measurements show high precision but low accuracy, suggesting a systematic error.

2
Express the following in proper scientific notation with appropriate significant figures: The speed of light is approximately 299,800,000 m/s.
+

Solution:

299,800,000 m/s = 2.998 × 10⁸ m/s

Since we're given "approximately" and the number ends in zeros, we should consider how many figures are truly known.

The most precise commonly used value is: 2.998 × 10⁸ m/s (4 significant figures)

For many calculations, 3.00 × 10⁸ m/s (3 significant figures) is sufficient.

3
A rectangular field has dimensions 127.3 ± 0.5 m by 89.6 ± 0.3 m. Calculate the area with proper uncertainty.
+

Solution:

Area = length × width = 127.3 × 89.6 = 11,406.08 m²

Uncertainty calculation for multiplication:

Relative uncertainty in length: δl/l = 0.5/127.3 = 0.00393

Relative uncertainty in width: δw/w = 0.3/89.6 = 0.00335

Combined relative uncertainty: √(0.00393² + 0.00335²) = 0.00517

Absolute uncertainty: δA = A × 0.00517 = 11,406 × 0.00517 = 59 m²

Final answer: A = 11,400 ± 60 m²

4
Convert 55 mph to km/h using dimensional analysis, and express your answer with appropriate significant figures.
+

Solution:

55 mph × (1.609 km/1 mile) = 55 × 1.609 km/h = 88.495 km/h

Significant figures analysis:

• 55 mph has 2 significant figures

• 1.609 km/mile is a conversion factor with 4 significant figures

Result should have 2 significant figures: 88 km/h

Note: For exact conversion factors (like 12 inches = 1 foot), the number of significant figures is unlimited.

5
Check whether the equation P = ½ρv²A is dimensionally consistent, where P is power, ρ is density, v is velocity, and A is area.
+

Solution:

Left side dimensions:

[P] = [ML²T⁻³] (power)

Right side dimensions:

[ρ] = [ML⁻³] (density)

[v²] = [L²T⁻²] (velocity squared)

[A] = [L²] (area)

[½ρv²A] = [ML⁻³][L²T⁻²][L²] = [ML⁻³⁺²⁺²T⁻²] = [MLT⁻²]

Comparison:

Left: [ML²T⁻³], Right: [MLT⁻²]

No, the equation is dimensionally inconsistent.

The equation might be for force (F = ½ρv²A) rather than power.

1.2 The International System of Units (SI)

The International System of Units (SI) is the modern form of the metric system, established by international treaty. It's built on seven fundamental base units that define all other measurements in physics.

The Seven SI Base Units

Quantity Unit Name Symbol Definition (2019 Revision)
TimesecondsBased on cesium-133 transition
LengthmetermDistance light travels in 1/299,792,458 s
MasskilogramkgBased on Planck constant h
Electric currentampereABased on elementary charge e
TemperaturekelvinKBased on Boltzmann constant k
Amount of substancemolemolBased on Avogadro constant NA
Luminous intensitycandelacdBased on luminous efficacy at 540 THz

🎓 The 2019 SI Redefinition:

On May 20, 2019, the SI underwent its most significant change since 1875. Instead of physical artifacts (like the International Prototype Kilogram), all units are now defined using fundamental constants of nature. This ensures universal reproducibility and eliminates the need for physical standards.

📝 Practice Problems:

Q3. Express the dimensions of kinetic energy (KE = ½mv²) in terms of M, L, T. +

Solution: KE = ½mv²

Dimensions: [KE] = [M][LT⁻¹]² = [M][L²T⁻²] = [ML²T⁻²]

This matches the dimension of energy/work in the table above.

Q4. A car travels 300 km in 4 hours. Express its speed as a vector quantity. +

Answer: Speed = 300 km ÷ 4 h = 75 km/h (scalar)

To make it a vector (velocity), we need direction: "75 km/h northeast" or "75 km/h at 45° from east"

Without direction, we can only specify the magnitude (speed).

1.2 The International System of Units (SI)

The International System of Units (SI) is the modern form of the metric system, established by international treaty. It's the universal language of science, ensuring that a measurement in Tokyo means the same thing in New York!

🌍 Why SI Matters:

Imagine if every country used different units for everything. The Mars Climate Orbiter crashed in 1999 because NASA used metric units while a contractor used imperial units. SI prevents such disasters!

The Seven SI Base Units

All measurements in physics can be expressed using just seven fundamental base units:

Quantity Unit Name Symbol Definition (2019 Revision)
TimesecondsBased on cesium-133 transition frequency
LengthmetermDistance light travels in 1/299,792,458 s
MasskilogramkgBased on Planck constant h
Electric currentampereABased on elementary charge e
TemperaturekelvinKBased on Boltzmann constant k
Amount of substancemolemolBased on Avogadro constant NA
Luminous intensitycandelacdBased on luminous efficacy at 540 THz

🎓 The 2019 SI Revolution:

On May 20, 2019, the SI underwent its most significant change since 1875. Instead of physical artifacts (like the International Prototype Kilogram), all units are now defined using fundamental constants of nature. This ensures universal reproducibility!

Common Derived Units

From these seven base units, we can derive all other units in physics:

  • Force: Newton (N) = kg⋅m⋅s⁻²
  • Energy: Joule (J) = kg⋅m²⋅s⁻²
  • Power: Watt (W) = kg⋅m²⋅s⁻³
  • Pressure: Pascal (Pa) = kg⋅m⁻¹⋅s⁻²

🤔 Practice Questions:

Q1. Why is the meter defined in terms of the speed of light instead of a physical rod? +

Answer: The speed of light is a fundamental constant of nature that's the same everywhere in the universe. A physical rod could expand with temperature, wear away, or be destroyed. Light-based definitions are invariable and accessible to any laboratory with the right equipment.

Q2. Express the unit of acceleration in terms of base SI units. +

Answer: Acceleration = velocity/time = (length/time)/time = length/time². So acceleration has units of m⋅s⁻².

📝 Numerical Problems:

Q3. Convert 5.2 km to meters and to micrometers. +

Solution:

To meters: 5.2 km = 5.2 × 10³ m = 5200 m

To micrometers: 5.2 km = 5.2 × 10³ m = 5.2 × 10³ × 10⁶ μm = 5.2 × 10⁹ μm

Q4. Express 250 MHz in Hz and in scientific notation. +

Solution:

250 MHz = 250 × 10⁶ Hz = 2.50 × 10⁸ Hz

This frequency is commonly used in computer processors.

1.3 Dimensional Analysis: The Physics Detective Tool

Every physical quantity has dimensions expressed in terms of fundamental quantities: Mass [M], Length [L], Time [T], Electric Current [I], Temperature [Θ], Amount of Substance [N], and Luminous Intensity [J].

🕵️ Think of Dimensional Analysis as Problem-Solving:

Like solving a puzzle, dimensional analysis helps physicists check if equations make sense, derive new relationships, and catch errors before they become costly mistakes in engineering and science!

Four Major Powers of Dimensional Analysis

1. Checking Dimensional Consistency

Any valid physical equation must be dimensionally consistent—every term must have the same dimensions.

📝 Detective Example: Is This Equation Valid?

Let's check: x = x₀ + v₀t + ½at²

  • Dimension of x: [L]
  • Dimension of x₀: [L]
  • Dimension of v₀t: [LT⁻¹][T] = [L]
  • Dimension of ½at²: [LT⁻²][T²] = [L]

Conclusion: ✅ All terms have dimension [L], so the equation is valid!

2. Deriving Relationships

We can discover how quantities are related by using dimensional analysis.

📝 Problem-Solving Example: Period of a Pendulum

Let's discover how the period T of a pendulum depends on its length l, mass m, and gravity g.

Step 1: Assume T = k × l^a × m^b × g^c

Step 2: Write dimensions: [T] = [L]^a × [M]^b × [LT⁻²]^c

Step 3: Equate powers:

  • For [M]: b = 0 (mass doesn't matter!)
  • For [T]: 1 = -2c → c = -1/2
  • For [L]: 0 = a + c → a = 1/2

Result: T = k√(l/g) - The period is independent of mass!

3. Converting Units

Dimensional analysis provides a systematic way to convert between unit systems.

4. Finding Dimensions of Constants

If we know a physical law, we can determine the dimensions of any constants.

⚠️ Limitations of Dimensional Analysis:

  • Dimensionless constants: Can't find values like π, 1/2, etc.
  • Complex functions: Fails for sin, cos, exponential functions
  • Sum relationships: Only works for product-type relationships

3. Converting Units Between Systems

Dimensional analysis provides a systematic way to convert between different unit systems.

📝 Unit Conversion Example: Newtons to Dynes

Convert 1 Newton (SI unit) to dynes (CGS unit).

Force has dimension [MLT⁻²]

  • In SI: 1 N = 1 kg⋅m⋅s⁻²
  • In CGS: 1 dyne = 1 g⋅cm⋅s⁻²
  • Conversions: 1 kg = 1000 g, 1 m = 100 cm

1 N = (1000 g)(100 cm)(s⁻²) = 10⁵ dynes

4. Finding Dimensions of Physical Constants

Use known physical laws to determine dimensions of constants.

📝 Constant Dimensions: Gravitational Constant G

From Newton's law: F = Gm₁m₂/r²

Solving for G: G = Fr²/(m₁m₂)

Dimensions: [G] = [MLT⁻²][L²]/([M][M]) = [M⁻¹L³T⁻²]

So G has units of m³⋅kg⁻¹⋅s⁻²

⚠️ Limitations of Dimensional Analysis:

  • Dimensionless constants: Can't find values like π, 1/2, etc.
  • Complex functions: Fails for sin, cos, exponential functions
  • Sum relationships: Only works for product-type relationships
  • Multiple variables: Limited by number of fundamental dimensions

📝 Practice Problems:

Q1. Find the dimensions of the gravitational constant G from F = Gm₁m₂/r² +

Solution: Rearrange: G = Fr²/(m₁m₂)

Dimensions: [G] = [MLT⁻²][L²]/([M][M]) = [M⁻¹L³T⁻²]

This means G has units of m³⋅kg⁻¹⋅s⁻²

Q2. Why can't dimensional analysis tell us that kinetic energy is ½mv² and not just mv²? +

Answer: The factor ½ is a dimensionless constant. Dimensional analysis can only determine the relationship between dimensions, not pure numbers. We need experimental data or deeper theory to find dimensionless factors.

Q3. Derive the relationship for the time period of oscillation of a mass-spring system. +

Solution: Assume T depends on mass m and spring constant k.

Let T = K × m^a × k^b (where K is dimensionless)

Dimensions: [T] = [M]^a × [MT⁻²]^b = [M^(a+b) T^(-2b)]

Equating powers: For [M]: a + b = 0, For [T]: -2b = 1

Solving: b = -1/2, a = 1/2

Result: T = K√(m/k) (K = 2π from full theory)

Q4. Convert 50 mph (miles per hour) to m/s using dimensional analysis. +

Solution: Use conversion factors:

1 mile = 1609 m, 1 hour = 3600 s

50 mph = 50 × (1609 m)/(3600 s) = 50 × 0.447 m/s = 22.4 m/s

This is about the speed limit in most residential areas.

1.3 Dimensional Analysis: The Physics Detective Tool

Every physical quantity has dimensions expressed in terms of fundamental quantities: Mass [M], Length [L], Time [T], Electric Current [I], Temperature [Θ], Amount of Substance [N], and Luminous Intensity [J].

🕵️ Think of Dimensional Analysis as Problem-Solving:

Like solving a puzzle, dimensional analysis helps physicists check if equations make sense, derive new relationships, and catch errors before they become costly mistakes in engineering and science!

Four Major Powers of Dimensional Analysis

1. Checking Dimensional Consistency

Any valid physical equation must be dimensionally consistent—every term must have the same dimensions.

📝 Detective Example: Is This Equation Valid?

Let's check: x = x₀ + v₀t + ½at²

  • Dimension of x: [L]
  • Dimension of x₀: [L]
  • Dimension of v₀t: [LT⁻¹][T] = [L]
  • Dimension of ½at²: [LT⁻²][T²] = [L]

Conclusion: ✅ All terms have dimension [L], so the equation is valid!

1.4 Precision, Significant Figures & Error Analysis

🎯 Real-World Reality Check:

Every measurement has uncertainty! Even the most precise instruments have limits. Understanding and quantifying this uncertainty is crucial for any scientific work - from space missions to medical devices.

Significant Figures: The Language of Precision

Significant figures tell us the precision of a measurement - they include all certain digits plus one uncertain digit.

📏 Rules for Significant Figures:

  1. Non-zero digits are always significant: 1.234 has 4 sig figs
  2. Zeros between digits are significant: 506 has 3 sig figs
  3. Leading zeros are not significant: 0.0078 has 2 sig figs
  4. Trailing zeros with decimal are significant: 90.00 has 4 sig figs
  5. Trailing zeros without decimal are ambiguous: Use scientific notation!

Operations with Significant Figures

Addition/Subtraction Rule:

Rule: Round to the fewest decimal places.

Example: 12.345 + 1.2 = 13.545 → 13.5

Multiplication/Division Rule:

Rule: Round to the fewest significant figures.

Example: 3.14 × 2.0 = 6.28 → 6.3

Error Analysis: Quantifying Uncertainty

In physics, every measurement has associated uncertainty. Here's how we handle it systematically:

🎯 Types of Errors:

  • Random Errors: Vary unpredictably (equipment fluctuations)
    Affect precision - reduced by averaging multiple measurements
  • Systematic Errors: Consistent bias (miscalibrated instrument)
    Affect accuracy - must be identified and corrected

📝 Worked Example: Measuring Pendulum Period

Five measurements of a pendulum period: 2.63s, 2.56s, 2.42s, 2.71s, 2.80s

Step 1 - Mean Value: (2.63 + 2.56 + 2.42 + 2.71 + 2.80) ÷ 5 = 2.62s

Step 2 - Absolute Errors: |2.62-2.63|=0.01, |2.62-2.56|=0.06, etc.

Step 3 - Mean Absolute Error: (0.01 + 0.06 + 0.20 + 0.09 + 0.18) ÷ 5 = 0.11s

Final Result: T = 2.62 ± 0.11 s

Percentage Error: (0.11/2.62) × 100% = 4.2%

Propagation of Errors

When we calculate results from multiple measurements, their errors combine according to specific rules:

📊 Error Combination Rules:

  • Addition/Subtraction: Absolute errors add
    ΔZ = ΔA + ΔB
  • Multiplication/Division: Relative errors add
    ΔZ/Z = ΔA/A + ΔB/B
  • Powers: Relative error × power
    ΔZ/Z = n(ΔA/A)

📝 Error Propagation Example: Density Calculation

Mass: m = (100 ± 2) g, Side length: L = (10 ± 0.1) cm

Find percentage error in density ρ = m/L³

Solution:

  • Relative error in mass: 2/100 = 0.02
  • Relative error in length: 0.1/10 = 0.01
  • Combined: Δρ/ρ = 0.02 + 3(0.01) = 0.05

Result: Percentage error = 5%

Detailed Error Analysis Examples

📝 Worked Example 1: Measuring the Period of a Pendulum

Five measurements of a pendulum period: 2.63s, 2.56s, 2.42s, 2.71s, 2.80s

Step 1 - Mean Value: (2.63 + 2.56 + 2.42 + 2.71 + 2.80) ÷ 5 = 2.62s

Step 2 - Absolute Errors:

  • |2.62-2.63| = 0.01s
  • |2.62-2.56| = 0.06s
  • |2.62-2.42| = 0.20s
  • |2.62-2.71| = 0.09s
  • |2.62-2.80| = 0.18s

Step 3 - Mean Absolute Error: (0.01 + 0.06 + 0.20 + 0.09 + 0.18) ÷ 5 = 0.11s

Final Result: T = 2.62 ± 0.11 s

Percentage Error: (0.11/2.62) × 100% = 4.2%

📝 Worked Example 2: Kinetic Energy Error Propagation

Mass: m = (4.0 ± 0.2) kg, Velocity: v = (10.0 ± 0.5) m/s

Find uncertainty in kinetic energy KE = ½mv²

Step 1 - Calculate mean KE: KE = ½(4.0)(10.0)² = 200 J

Step 2 - Find relative errors:

  • Relative error in mass: 0.2/4.0 = 0.05
  • Relative error in velocity: 0.5/10.0 = 0.05

Step 3 - Combine errors: ΔKE/KE = 0.05 + 2(0.05) = 0.15 = 15%

Step 4 - Find absolute error: ΔKE = 0.15 × 200 J = 30 J

Final Result: KE = (200 ± 30) J

Accuracy vs. Precision

🎯 Target Analogy:

  • High Accuracy, High Precision: Arrows clustered tightly on the bullseye
  • Low Accuracy, High Precision: Arrows clustered tightly, but far from bullseye
  • High Accuracy, Low Precision: Arrows scattered, but average hits bullseye
  • Low Accuracy, Low Precision: Arrows scattered and average is off-target

🤔 Master Your Understanding:

Q1. How many significant figures are in 0.00506 and 1200? +

Answer: 0.00506 has 3 significant figures (leading zeros don't count). 1200 is ambiguous - could be 2, 3, or 4 sig figs. Better to write as 1.20 × 10³ (3 sig figs) or 1.200 × 10³ (4 sig figs).

Q2. If length L = (5.0 ± 0.1) m, what is the percentage error in area A = L²? +

Solution: For A = L², the relative error is doubled.

Relative error in L: 0.1/5.0 = 0.02 = 2%

Relative error in A: 2 × 2% = 4%

Q3. Calculate: (12.345 + 1.2) × 3.14159. Apply significant figure rules correctly. +

Solution:

Step 1: Addition - 12.345 + 1.2 = 13.545 → 13.5 (limited by 1.2's decimal places)

Step 2: Multiplication - 13.5 × 3.14159 = 42.41... → 42.4 (limited by 13.5's 3 sig figs)

Q4. A measurement gives 25.6 ± 0.3. What is the percentage error? +

Solution:

Percentage error = (absolute error / measured value) × 100%

= (0.3 / 25.6) × 100% = 1.2%

This is a quite precise measurement!

Q5. If resistance R = V/I where V = (12.0 ± 0.2) V and I = (2.5 ± 0.1) A, find R with its uncertainty. +

Solution:

Mean resistance: R = 12.0/2.5 = 4.8 Ω

Relative errors: ΔV/V = 0.2/12.0 = 0.0167, ΔI/I = 0.1/2.5 = 0.04

Combined relative error: ΔR/R = 0.0167 + 0.04 = 0.0567

Absolute error: ΔR = 0.0567 × 4.8 = 0.27 ≈ 0.3 Ω

Result: R = (4.8 ± 0.3) Ω
